review.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
review.abstract: In this work, we introduce graphical models for multiplayer game theory and provide powerful algorithms for calculating their Nash balances in certain cases. An n-player game is given by an undirected graph for n-nodes and a set of n-local matrices. Interpretation is that the payout to player i is entirely determined by the actions of player i and his neighbors in the graph, and therefore the payout matrix for player i is indexed only by these players. We therefore consider the global n-player game to be composed of interacting local games, with each game involving far fewer players. Each player's action may have a global impact, but it happens through the spread of local influences. Our most important technical result is an efficient algorithm for calculating Nash balances when the underlying graph is a tree (or can be turned into a tree with few node-mings).

metadata.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
metadata.abstractText: We introduce a compact graph-theoretic repre­ sentation for multi-party game theory. Our main result is a provably correct and efficient algo­ rithm for computing approximate Nash equilibria in one-stage games represented by trees or sparse graphs.
